entry.title: Hello Docusaurus - Building My Personal Blog
entry.summary: My journey of setting up a personal blog using Docusaurus and GitHub Pages
entry.content:
Hello world! ğŸ‘‹

Welcome to my personal blog. I'm Guangze Yang, a Control Systems researcher at Ibaraki University, and I'm excited to share my journey of building this blog using Docusaurus.

Why I Chose Docusaurusâ€‹

As someone who works primarily in control systems and automation, I spend a lot of time writing technical documentation and research papers. When I decided to start a personal blog, I wanted something that would feel natural for someone with my background - clean, organized, and developer-friendly.

After exploring various options like WordPress and Jekyll, I landed on Docusaurus for several compelling reasons:

ğŸ“ Documentation-First Approachâ€‹

Having spent countless hours writing technical documentation, I appreciate Docusaurus's philosophy of treating documentation as a first-class citizen. The seamless integration between docs and blog posts feels natural for someone who thinks in terms of structured information.

âš›ï¸ React-Based Flexibilityâ€‹

As someone who enjoys tinkering with web technologies, the React foundation gives me the flexibility to customize components when needed, while still providing sensible defaults out of the box.

ğŸš€ GitHub Pages Integrationâ€‹

The straightforward deployment to GitHub Pages was a huge selling point. With GitHub Actions, I can write in Markdown, push to my repository, and have the site automatically deployed - perfect for my workflow.

Setting Up the Blogâ€‹

The setup process was surprisingly smooth, though I did encounter a few gotchas that are worth sharing:

Initial Configurationâ€‹

The most critical part was getting the docusaurus.config.js right, especially for GitHub Pages deployment:

const config = {
  title: 'Youkoutaku',
  tagline: 'Endure hardship without bitterness, remember your roots even in success.',
  url: 'https://youkoutaku.github.io',
  baseUrl: '/', // This was crucial!
  organizationName: 'youkoutaku',
  projectName: 'docusaurus-youkoutaku',
  // ... rest of config
};

Pro tip: Make sure your baseUrl is set to '/' for user GitHub Pages (username.github.io), not the repository name!

Multilingual Supportâ€‹

Since I work in an international environment and want to share content in multiple languages, I configured support for English, Chinese, and Japanese:

i18n: {
  defaultLocale: 'en',
  locales: ['en', 'zh-Hans', 'ja'],
},

While English will be my primary language for blogging, having the infrastructure in place for future multilingual content feels like a smart decision.

What I Plan to Shareâ€‹

This blog will be a mix of technical insights and personal reflections:

ğŸ¤– Control Systems & Automationâ€‹

  • Research insights from my work at Ibaraki University
  • Practical applications of control theory
  • Industry trends in automation and robotics

ğŸ’» Software Developmentâ€‹

  • Tools and techniques I discover in my research
  • Open-source projects I'm working on
  • Web development experiments (like this blog!)

ğŸ“š Learning & Growthâ€‹

  • Academic journey and research experiences
  • Cultural observations from my time in Japan
  • Language learning adventures

ğŸ”§ Technical Tutorialsâ€‹

  • Step-by-step guides for tools I find useful
  • Documentation best practices
  • Development workflow optimizations

The Road Aheadâ€‹

Building this blog has reminded me why I love working with well-designed tools. Docusaurus strikes the perfect balance between simplicity and power - I can focus on writing while having the flexibility to customize when needed.

I'm particularly excited about:

  • Integrating with my research workflow: Using this platform to share research insights and methodologies
  • Building a knowledge base: Creating comprehensive documentation for projects I work on
  • Connecting with the community: Engaging with other researchers and developers who share similar interests

A Personal Noteâ€‹

The tagline of this blog - "Endure hardship without bitterness, remember your roots even in success" - reflects a philosophy that has guided me through my academic and professional journey. I hope this blog can be a place where I not only share technical knowledge but also reflect on the human side of research and development.

Whether you're here for the technical content, the personal insights, or you just stumbled upon this blog by accident, I'm glad you're here. Feel free to reach out through any of the channels listed on this site - I'd love to connect!

What's Next?â€‹

In my next few posts, I plan to dive deeper into:

  1. Setting up the complete GitHub Actions workflow for automated deployment
  2. Customizing Docusaurus themes and components
  3. My current research project in adaptive control systems
  4. Tools and techniques for effective technical writing

Stay tuned, and thank you for joining me on this journey!

This blog is built with Docusaurus and deployed on GitHub Pages. You can find the source code here.

entry.title: Work & Life Framework
entry.summary: A simple framework for managing work and life - cycles of reading, writing, building, and self-care
entry.content:
Work Framework: Read â†’ Write â†’ Buildâ€‹

A simple cycle for productive work:

  • If you have no ideas â†’ Read (Get new information or inspiration)
  • If you have ideas but can't express them â†’ Write (Organize your thoughts and find your own voice)
  • If you have ideas and know how to act on them â†’ Build (Create something)

Life Framework: Sleep â†’ Eat â†’ Workout/Focus â†’ Sleepâ€‹

A fundamental cycle for healthy living:

  • If your body feels tired â†’ Sleep (Restore your energy)
  • If your mind feels tired â†’ Work out (Refresh your brain) / Focus (Reduce mental clutter)
  • If you feel physically unwell â†’ Eat healthy and sleep well (see a doctor if needed)

Framework Benefitsâ€‹

Work Cycle Advantages:

  • Reading builds knowledge and sparks creativity
  • Writing clarifies thinking and develops communication skills
  • Building transforms ideas into tangible results

Life Cycle Advantages:

  • Sleep provides physical and mental restoration
  • Nutrition fuels both body and brain performance
  • Exercise/Focus maintains mental clarity and physical health

Integration:

  • These cycles complement each other naturally
  • Simple decision-making: identify your current state and take the appropriate action
  • Sustainable approach that prevents burnout while maintaining productivity

A minimalist approach to managing the essential elements of work and life.

entry.title: My Knowledge Management System | Zotero, Obsidian, Readwise, Notion
entry.summary: Complete guide to a cross-platform knowledge management workflow integrating academic research, personal learning, and life management
entry.content:
In today's information-rich world, developing a personalized knowledge management system is essential for anyone engaged in academic research, continuous learning, and maintaining balanced productivity. After much experimentation, I've developed a cross-platform workflow that effectively bridges my academic research, personal learning journey, and daily life management. Here's how I've structured my digital ecosystem.

1. Academic Research Workflow ğŸ’»â€‹

My research workflow revolves around two cornerstone software that form the foundation of my academic productivity. I primarily do research on a desktop.

1.1. Zotero: My Research Libraryâ€‹

Zotero serves as the central hub for all my research documents. Here's how I use it:

  • PDF Management: All academic papers and technical books are stored and categorized here with tags
  • Annotation & Reading: I annotate and highlight papers directly within Zotero, capturing key contents during my reading
  • Research To-Do Lists: Using Zotero plugin Notero, my reading queue and priorities sync to Notion, giving me a clear overview for tasks

1.2 Obsidian: My Knowledge Laboratoryâ€‹

Obsidian acts as my personal knowledge lab where raw ideas become structured knowledge:

  • Research Notes Hub: I take detailed notes from Zotero and web resources
  • Mathematical Notation: As a control systems and robotics student, I heavily use MathJax for equations
  • Bidirectional Linking: Easy connections between concepts

1.3 Publication Workflowâ€‹

When research reaches the publication stage, I rely on the following tools:

  • GitHub: For version control and blog uploads
  • VSCode + TeX / Overleaf: For preparing formal LaTeX documents

2. Personal Learning ğŸ’» & ğŸ“±â€‹

Beyond academic research, I maintain a continuous learning system:

2.1 Content Discoveryâ€‹

  • Readwise Reader: My primary tool for blog RSS feeds, YouTube videos, Reddit discussions and X content
  • Inoreader: For staying current with world events by news RSS feeds
  • E-reading: I use Kindle and Apple Books for longer-form content

2.2 Readwise: Knowledge Integrationâ€‹

The magic happens when these inputs are processed:

  • Readwise: Collects highlights and annotations across all platforms
  • Integration: My highlights and notes automatically sync to Notion and NotebookLM

3. Life Management System ğŸ’» & ğŸ“±â€‹

A productive mind requires an organized life. Here is how I manage my day-to-day life:

3.1 Calendar & Task Managementâ€‹

  • Apple Calendar â‡” Google Calendar â‡” Notion Calendar: Handles all fixed-time commitments like meetings and courses, synced for cross-platform consistency
  • Notion Tasks board: Dashboard to track my project, research and learning

3.2 Notion: Journal & Reflectionâ€‹

  • Journal: Both lab work and personal reflections are saved in Notion
  • Visible on Calendar: I link Notion database to Calendar for easy review

The Philosophy Behind My Systemâ€‹

This setup isn't just about using the right toolsâ€”it's about creating an external brain that augments my thinking. By maintaining a clear separation between academic research, personal learning, and life management, I can focus on each domain without distraction, while enabling cross-domain insights when needed.

Tool Roles Summaryâ€‹

  • Zotero serves as the primary library that saves all my academic documents
  • Obsidian excels at academic work due to its support for mathematical notation and offline functions
  • Notion acts as a cloud-based hub, connecting various information domains through task management, journal, research planning and more on multi platforms
  • Readwise functions as a collector, ensuring that tracking valuable information. Readwise Reader acts as filter, extracting highlights from various sources

ğŸ’¡ One notable advantage is that Readwise is the only paid service in this entire system, making the setup both cost-effective and highly functional.

System Benefitsâ€‹

Academic Research:

  • Centralized paper management with Zotero
  • Mathematical notation support in Obsidian
  • Seamless citation and reference workflow

Personal Learning:

  • Multi-source content aggregation
  • Automated highlight collection
  • Cross-platform accessibility

Life Organization:

  • Unified calendar system
  • Task and project tracking
  • Reflective journaling integrated with planning

Cost Efficiency:

  • Only one paid service (Readwise) in the entire workflow
  • Leverages free tiers of powerful tools
  • Scalable based on usage needs

As my needs evolve, this system continues to adapt, but the core philosophy remains the same: Capture everything that interests me, process information thoughtfully, and create meaningful connections between ideas.

I've kept this overview concise, but there are countless tips and advanced features for Obsidian, Notion, and Zotero that can improve your workflow. What knowledge management system have you developed? I'd love to hear about your tools or approach!

Academic Research Approachâ€‹

In university research, when studying new theories, I would:

  • Study papers to grasp the field's content
  • Program while reading papers in a structured learning cycle

Previous Industry Experience (Summer Internship)â€‹

During my previous internship, I experienced corporate development where:

Actual Resultsâ€‹

Working on completely unfamiliar content presented difficulties:

  • Shallow understanding led to misaligned problem analysis and solution evaluation

Learning Through Implementationâ€‹

Theme: Distributed power source system development centered on power conditioners
Department: Energy Business Division, Software Development Group

Key Insightsâ€‹

1. Industry vs Research Differencesâ€‹

Compared to research, safety considerations, error tolerance, and variation management are critical. Changing one function requires considering safety implications, guarantees, and impacts on other affected areas.

2. Product Development Complexityâ€‹

For commercial products spanning hardware to software, the volume of design specifications is overwhelming. It's impossible for one person to understand everything completely. Even within the same group, members have different responsibilities and expertise areas, making communication and collaboration essential.

I had many opportunities to talk with senior employees. They listened to discussions about work content, job hunting, and casual conversations, which made me very happy. All employees were kind, and I was particularly comforted by the brightness of young employees.

  • Skill Alignment: Participating in a theme that matched skills learned at university helped me gain a concrete image of how to apply my expertise in the development field
  • Real Work Experience: Experiencing actual work content allowed me to understand professional work styles and workflow
  • Career Guidance: Through interactions with many senior employees, I gained valuable advice and experiences useful for future career development

  • Seamless integration with Apple ecosystem

Android Devices:

  • Dropbox or WebDAV work best
  • OneDrive also supported

For Large Vaults:

  • Obsidian Sync (official paid service) - Most reliable for large vaults
  • Git-based sync - For technical users with version control needs
  • Self-hosted solutions - Using personal cloud servers

Free Alternatives:

  • iCloud (Apple ecosystem)
  • OneDrive (5GB free)
  • Dropbox (2GB free)
  • Self-hosted WebDAV servers

Troubleshooting Tipsâ€‹

  1. Ensure consistent vault names across all devices
  2. Check internet connectivity before syncing
  3. Avoid simultaneous editing on multiple devices
  4. Regular backups are recommended for important vaults
  5. Monitor sync status in the plugin interface
